description: The Systems Security Certified Practitioner (SSCP) certification is one of the leading certifications from (ISC)2. This is a certification for hands on practitioners with the responsibility of making sure IT security concerns are addressed in an enterprise environment and is designed for IT security professionals with one or more years of field experience who are seeking to advance their career by validating their knowledge and experience. If IT security is your preferred career path, then the SSCP is a great starting point for you.
name: Systems Security Certified Practitioner
subtitle: SSCP

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don introduce the viewers to the (ISC)2 SSCP certification. They discuss the requirements to becoming SSCP certified as well as the general topic areas covered by the certification.
episodes.title: Overview of SSCP
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:08,295 --> 00:00:10,078
[SOUND] Welcome back to ITProTV.

2
00:00:10,078 --> 00:00:11,053
I'm Don Pezet.

3
00:00:11,053 --> 00:00:14,190
Today, our guest speaker
with us is Mr Adam Gordon.

4
00:00:14,190 --> 00:00:14,987
How are you doing this morning Adam?

5
00:00:14,987 --> 00:00:16,484
>> Good.
Good morning everybody.

6
00:00:16,484 --> 00:00:17,007
Very good.

7
00:00:17,007 --> 00:00:20,402
>> And what we wanna do is
we want to take a minute to

8
00:00:20,402 --> 00:00:25,104
basically christen our new show
that we're launching on SSCP,

9

the latest in the entry of many
security certifications that we have.

10
00:00:30,262 --> 00:00:34,835
And we wanna take a few minutes just
to kind of describe what the SSCP is.

11
00:00:34,835 --> 00:00:37,965
Who it's a good fit for, and
how you go about obtaining it

12
00:00:37,965 --> 00:00:42,405
before we dive into all of our shows that
give you the information that we need.

13
00:00:42,405 --> 00:00:43,185
>> Very good.

14
00:00:43,185 --> 00:00:44,895
>> So Adam, why don't you get us started,

15
00:00:44,895 --> 00:00:49,100
just kind of give us a little overview of
the SSCP, and what the certification is.

16
00:00:49,100 --> 00:00:53,350
>> Absolutely, so the ideas behind
the SSCP, the system security certified

17
00:00:53,350 --> 00:00:58,350
practitioner by the way, that's what SSCP
stands for, an (ISC)2 certification.

18
00:00:58,350 --> 00:01:01,050
A certification for
a hands on practitioner, so

19
00:01:01,050 --> 00:01:05,540
much more so than somebody who is
going to be a more senior manager.

20
00:01:05,540 --> 00:01:09,729
This is a person who is gonna have hands
on day to day responsibility for making

21
00:01:09,729 --> 00:01:14,314
sure that IT, specifically IT security
concerns in the enterprise are addressed.

22
00:01:14,314 --> 00:01:18,337
So, they'll be the people that will be
in the trenches dealing with firewalls,

23
00:01:18,337 --> 00:01:22,954
dealing with networks, setting up wireless
security, setting up virtualized security,

24
00:01:22,954 --> 00:01:24,687
and doing that on a regular basis.

25
00:01:24,687 --> 00:01:28,221
And so, we typically see somebody
with a year of experience going

26
00:01:28,221 --> 00:01:30,460
through certification like this.

27
00:01:30,460 --> 00:01:35,560
Some hands on real world experience along
with some theory behind some of the areas

28
00:01:35,560 --> 00:01:38,940
that are gonna be covered in the common
body of knowledge, what we call the CBK.

29
00:01:38,940 --> 00:01:40,129
Which is the reference point for this.

30
00:01:40,129 --> 00:01:44,350
And you really got to be, if you're out
there thinking about becoming an SSCP,

31
00:01:44,350 --> 00:01:47,690
be looking to market your skills
to your potential employers.

32
00:01:47,690 --> 00:01:52,185
By saying this is a credential that
validates me being able to do these things

33
00:01:52,185 --> 00:01:54,990
real-time as I go into the environment.

34
00:01:54,990 --> 00:01:57,198
And I'm gonna be able to
help you setup your network,

35
00:01:57,198 --> 00:02:00,740
will be able to help you secure it,
help you monitor it, but

36
00:02:00,740 --> 00:02:03,930
also help you to understand
what goes on in a day to day.

37
00:02:03,930 --> 00:02:05,410
>> Yeah, and that's a really good point.

38
00:02:05,410 --> 00:02:10,700
The SSCP, you'll hear it described a lot
of times in conjunction with this CISSP,

39
00:02:10,700 --> 00:02:12,960
which is another
certification from (ISC)2.

40
00:02:12,960 --> 00:02:17,050
The CISSP very highly
regarded certification, but

41
00:02:17,050 --> 00:02:20,002
it is focused more around
that security manager.

42
00:02:20,002 --> 00:02:23,300
That high-level knowledge, that
a person who's been in the trenches for

43
00:02:23,300 --> 00:02:24,960
a long time.

44
00:02:24,960 --> 00:02:27,410
The SSCP, that's more of the doer,

45
00:02:27,410 --> 00:02:29,830
the person who's actually
getting their hands dirty.

46
00:02:29,830 --> 00:02:32,640
Getting these systems put in place,
protecting the network, so

47
00:02:32,640 --> 00:02:33,470
it's really cool.

48
00:02:33,470 --> 00:02:35,650
It covers a lot of neat technologies.

49
00:02:35,650 --> 00:02:38,370
Adam, what are some of the things
that we cover in SSCP?

50
00:02:38,370 --> 00:02:41,891
>> So, the criteria that we're gonna look
at are what we call the common body of

51
00:02:41,891 --> 00:02:42,782
knowledge areas.

52
00:02:42,782 --> 00:02:45,448
There are seven of them,
are gonna be access control.

53
00:02:45,448 --> 00:02:48,720
So we're gonna be talking about all
the things associated with how we control

54
00:02:48,720 --> 00:02:49,560
access.

55
00:02:49,560 --> 00:02:53,030
The policies, the standards, the
implementation models, things like that.

56
00:02:53,030 --> 00:02:55,990
We'll take a look at security operations,
and administration.

57
00:02:55,990 --> 00:02:58,828
So we'll be talking about what
a security administrator does,

58
00:02:58,828 --> 00:03:01,506
what are the kind of things that
add to management policies,

59
00:03:01,506 --> 00:03:03,780
things of that nature that
you might be looking at.

60
00:03:03,780 --> 00:03:06,195
We'll take a look at monitoring,
and analysis.

61
00:03:06,195 --> 00:03:11,670
And talk about continuous monitoring,
how we monitor, how we look at results.

62
00:03:11,670 --> 00:03:16,460
Things such as firewall logs,
intrusion protection, and defense systems,

63
00:03:16,460 --> 00:03:17,610
things of that nature.

64
00:03:17,610 --> 00:03:20,690
We'll be taking a look at risk response,
and recovery.

65
00:03:20,690 --> 00:03:22,280
So, what is risk management?

66
00:03:22,280 --> 00:03:24,310
How important is risk,
threat, vulnerability?

67
00:03:24,310 --> 00:03:25,340
How do we address those?

68
00:03:25,340 --> 00:03:26,580
How do we define them?

69
00:03:26,580 --> 00:03:28,800
What is business continuity?

70
00:03:28,800 --> 00:03:30,290
What is disaster recovery?

71
00:03:30,290 --> 00:03:34,080
How do we plan for those events that may,
or may not be on the horizon for

72
00:03:34,080 --> 00:03:37,340
us initially as we open
up our minds to security.

73
00:03:37,340 --> 00:03:41,290
But ultimately as we know, when we
are security management professionals, and

74
00:03:41,290 --> 00:03:44,240
security practitioners,
we have to address risk every day.

75
00:03:44,240 --> 00:03:45,610
And so, how do we do that?

76
00:03:45,610 --> 00:03:49,069
Cryptography, and the use of cryptography
in networks to provide security.

77
00:03:49,069 --> 00:03:52,530
[INAUDIBLE] Have been a lot of talk
over the last couple of years about what

78
00:03:52,530 --> 00:03:56,565
security is, and is not, based on being
able to look at people's email, or listen

79
00:03:56,565 --> 00:04:00,339
to their phone calls, all sorts of things
that we may, or may not be aware of.

80
00:04:00,339 --> 00:04:01,064
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

81
00:04:01,064 --> 00:04:03,691
the security practitioner
takes a look at that, and

82
00:04:03,691 --> 00:04:06,737
from the practitioner perspective
would say to a business,

83
00:04:06,737 --> 00:04:10,310
this is what we need to do in order
to implement a secure solution.

84
00:04:10,310 --> 00:04:12,210
These are the kind of
algorithms we may use, and

85
00:04:12,210 --> 00:04:15,900
these are the kind of cryptographic
solutions we may wanna put in place.

86
00:04:15,900 --> 00:04:18,950
These are the secure protocols
that we want to use.

87
00:04:18,950 --> 00:04:22,990
For networks, and communication,
we take a look at the bread, and

88
00:04:22,990 --> 00:04:25,660
butter of what a security
practitioner does everyday.

89
00:04:25,660 --> 00:04:29,260
We think about the networks,
the telecommunications solutions that they

90
00:04:29,260 --> 00:04:31,720
deploy, whether they're wireless,
or wired.

91
00:04:31,720 --> 00:04:35,297
Whether they are looking at remote access,
or people that work in an office,

92
00:04:35,297 --> 00:04:39,041
they're going to look at firewalls,
wireless technology, all the things that

93
00:04:39,041 --> 00:04:42,804
are associated with network access,
really top to bottom, across that stack.

94
00:04:42,804 --> 00:04:47,499
And then we finish up with malicious code,
and activity, one of my most

95
00:04:47,499 --> 00:04:52,290
favorite sections in the sense that I
do a lot of work around these areas.

96
00:04:52,290 --> 00:04:55,975
Is to spend time talking about the things
that can go wrong in a system, And

97
00:04:55,975 --> 00:04:58,870
understand how to identify them,
and be aware of them.

98
00:04:58,870 --> 00:05:03,260
So that way we are able to zero in on the
issues we have, and as a result hopefully,

99
00:05:03,260 --> 00:05:08,210
identify the problems with malware,
trojans, worms, anything that could go

100
00:05:08,210 --> 00:05:12,690
on with, not only transmissions of those,
but countermeasures associated with them.

101
00:05:12,690 --> 00:05:14,250
>> So, those are our seven domains.

102
00:05:14,250 --> 00:05:16,500
These are the knowledge areas
that we need to focus in,

103
00:05:16,500 --> 00:05:20,028
if we plan on getting
the SSCP certification.

104
00:05:20,028 --> 00:05:23,090
So Adam, and let's say that I look at
that list, and I say, you know what,

105
00:05:23,090 --> 00:05:24,320
I'm an expert on all of that stuff.

106
00:05:24,320 --> 00:05:25,760
I'm ready to take the exam today.

107
00:05:25,760 --> 00:05:28,030
So, what do I need to know about the exam?

108
00:05:28,030 --> 00:05:30,940
>> So
the exam is gonna be computer-based today.

109
00:05:30,940 --> 00:05:35,631
Years ago, if you were sitting for an exam
from (ISC)2, they were paper-based exams.

110
00:05:35,631 --> 00:05:38,760
They were going to use a scantron bubble,
and answer sheet, and

111
00:05:38,760 --> 00:05:42,190
you would sit for four hours for this,
or three hours for this exam rather.

112
00:05:42,190 --> 00:05:45,850
And it would have been 125 questions, and
you would have had to go through, and

113
00:05:45,850 --> 00:05:47,310
write out all the answers by hand.

114
00:05:47,310 --> 00:05:48,850
Today, they're computerized.

115
00:05:48,850 --> 00:05:52,085
You can go into a secure testing center,
and you can take the exam.

116
00:05:52,085 --> 00:05:56,612
It is still 125 questions, you need to
score 700, or better in order to pass.

117
00:05:56,612 --> 00:06:00,737
And you will need to make sure you have
at least one year of proven experience in

118
00:06:00,737 --> 00:06:04,555
the field in one, or more of the seven
areas we just identified for you.

119
00:06:04,555 --> 00:06:08,813
That you can document on your application,
and then you're able to validate that

120
00:06:08,813 --> 00:06:13,005
experience through the application
process after you take the exam.

121
00:06:13,005 --> 00:06:15,975
And so, what happens is,
you go, and sit for the exam.

122
00:06:15,975 --> 00:06:17,185
Pass the exam.

123
00:06:17,185 --> 00:06:20,115
Then you go through an application
process through (ISC)2,

124
00:06:20,115 --> 00:06:21,607
where you submit an application.

125
00:06:21,607 --> 00:06:26,200
Validate your three-year resume, and your
credentials that you have the experience.

126
00:06:26,200 --> 00:06:27,350
And then you're able to,

127
00:06:27,350 --> 00:06:31,070
along with the fee that you pay to apply,
send all that paperwork into (ISC)2.

128
00:06:31,070 --> 00:06:34,470
There's a small delay,
while they go through the application.

129
00:06:34,470 --> 00:06:37,350
You may randomly,
be chosen to have an application audited.

130
00:06:37,350 --> 00:06:40,470
If you are, you may be asked some
follow up questions about 10%

131
00:06:40,470 --> 00:06:43,040
of people on average get audited randomly.

132
00:06:43,040 --> 00:06:46,320
But more often than not, you simply
go through the application process.

133
00:06:46,320 --> 00:06:49,260
Within about a week, give, or
take depending on the time of the year,

134
00:06:49,260 --> 00:06:53,280
you hear back that you've been accepted
as long as your credentials hold up, and

135
00:06:53,280 --> 00:06:55,170
everything is validated on your resume.

136
00:06:55,170 --> 00:06:58,310
And your granted in this
case the SSCP credential.

137
00:06:58,310 --> 00:07:00,030
Once your granted that credential,

138
00:07:00,030 --> 00:07:03,530
you will have a three-year cycle where
you are expected as a professional

139
00:07:03,530 --> 00:07:07,890
in the field practicing your
craft to accrue CPE credits.

140
00:07:07,890 --> 00:07:11,720
You must do 40 credits a year in order to
be able to maintain your certification,

141
00:07:11,720 --> 00:07:14,430
120 credits over a three-year cycle.

142
00:07:14,430 --> 00:07:17,970
You are then able to provide
documentation about those credits through

143
00:07:17,970 --> 00:07:19,890
an online portal, through the web.

144
00:07:19,890 --> 00:07:22,610
You submit them, and
then you pay your membership fees, and

145
00:07:22,610 --> 00:07:26,720
renew your certification on
a three-year cycle based on those fees.

146
00:07:26,720 --> 00:07:31,340
Assuming you stay active, and you get
your CPEs, there is no re-certification

147
00:07:31,340 --> 00:07:35,390
process at this point,
meaning you don't have to re-sir the exam.

148
00:07:35,390 --> 00:07:39,160
However, if you let your certification
lapse, if you don't stay active, you will

149
00:07:39,160 --> 00:07:42,570
need to re-sit the exam, so it's really
a question of what you choose to do.

150
00:07:42,570 --> 00:07:45,950
But there are professionals out there that
just simply want to re-certify every three

151
00:07:45,950 --> 00:07:48,605
years, because they wanna prove they're
staying current on the technology,

152
00:07:48,605 --> 00:07:50,015
and up to date with the knowledge.

153
00:07:50,015 --> 00:07:52,275
So, truly up to you at the end of the day.

154
00:07:52,275 --> 00:07:54,284
>> Yeah, one thing I like to
highlight about this, (ISC)2,

155
00:07:54,284 --> 00:07:57,135
that they really stress having experience.

156
00:07:57,135 --> 00:07:59,415
And Adam said it for the SSCP,

157
00:07:59,415 --> 00:08:05,145
you're really supposed to have the either
one-year of actual in field experience.

158
00:08:05,145 --> 00:08:07,900
Or sometimes you hear
people say the equivalency.

159
00:08:07,900 --> 00:08:11,510
Well, when you submit your
paperwork to the (ISC)2,

160
00:08:11,510 --> 00:08:14,300
you show that you have to have
documented one-year of experience.

161
00:08:14,300 --> 00:08:16,210
Its not like CompTIA, or
where it can be equivalent.

162
00:08:16,210 --> 00:08:18,580
You actually need to have that experience.

163
00:08:18,580 --> 00:08:20,140
So, this is a certification
that is designed for

164
00:08:20,140 --> 00:08:23,240
people that are already working
in the security field, or

165
00:08:23,240 --> 00:08:27,200
at least working with security
related infrastructure, and equipment.

166
00:08:27,200 --> 00:08:27,930
What if you don't?

167
00:08:27,930 --> 00:08:29,590
If you're one of those
people that doesn't?

168
00:08:29,590 --> 00:08:33,520
If you're just getting started, and you've
decided that security is the way to go,

169
00:08:33,520 --> 00:08:37,020
then SSCP is probably not
the certification for you right now.

170
00:08:37,020 --> 00:08:41,170
Instead you should be looking to
things like CompTIA Security Plus.

171
00:08:41,170 --> 00:08:44,480
With Security Plus you get the base
knowledge, it's actually a very similar,

172
00:08:44,480 --> 00:08:48,540
not as in depth, but
very similar to what we see here in SSCP.

173
00:08:48,540 --> 00:08:50,550
But it is designed for
people who maybe just starting out,

174
00:08:50,550 --> 00:08:53,520
who may not have any field experience.

175
00:08:53,520 --> 00:08:55,800
But if you're already working the field,
and you're looking for

176
00:08:55,800 --> 00:08:59,910
a way to validate that knowledge
SSCP is the certification to use.

177
00:08:59,910 --> 00:09:02,000
That's one thing I've
always like about (ISC)2,

178
00:09:02,000 --> 00:09:04,370
let's pull up these requirements again.

179
00:09:04,370 --> 00:09:09,280
It is you'll notice how they say,
obtain the required experience, and

180
00:09:09,280 --> 00:09:13,990
then in your study for exam used
these optional educational tools.

181
00:09:13,990 --> 00:09:17,770
In other words, if you have all the field
experience, you don't need study tools.

182
00:09:17,770 --> 00:09:19,080
You can just go, and take the exam.

183
00:09:19,080 --> 00:09:21,680
Go ahead, and have it.

184
00:09:21,680 --> 00:09:24,640
But if you work in it, but
not in all the areas, and you wanna

185
00:09:24,640 --> 00:09:28,215
round off that information, that's where
things like our show come in handy.

186
00:09:28,215 --> 00:09:32,395
The official training, the textbooks,
the self-paced stuff that's out there.

187
00:09:32,395 --> 00:09:35,605
All those different things help to make
sure you've got that base of knowledge to

188
00:09:35,605 --> 00:09:38,275
be ready, for what's on the exam.

189
00:09:38,275 --> 00:09:40,025
>> One other thing we wanna
make sure you're aware of,

190
00:09:40,025 --> 00:09:42,900
as well when you go through
the endorsement process,

191
00:09:42,900 --> 00:09:47,300
this idea of after you actually pass
the exam, the application process.

192
00:09:47,300 --> 00:09:49,520
We call it formally,
the endorsement process.

193
00:09:49,520 --> 00:09:52,150
You have a nine-month window,
(ISC)2 gives you time,

194
00:09:52,150 --> 00:09:55,330
in other words, after you pass the exam,
in order to apply.

195
00:09:55,330 --> 00:09:57,458
So, while you wanna do
it as soon as possible,

196
00:09:57,458 --> 00:10:00,680
we understand that there are needs
to be a window where things happen,

197
00:10:00,680 --> 00:10:02,940
you're busy with work, or whatever.

198
00:10:02,940 --> 00:10:05,638
And so, you're given a window where
you then, those scores are good.

199
00:10:05,638 --> 00:10:07,895
But they're good for
up to nine months for you to apply.

200
00:10:07,895 --> 00:10:10,383
You don't wanna wait too long,
but you can go out, and

201
00:10:10,383 --> 00:10:13,525
get your paperwork in order to get
somebody to formally endorse you,

202
00:10:13,525 --> 00:10:16,420
make sure you have the credential
information in your resume.

203
00:10:16,420 --> 00:10:19,480
You need to validate your experience,
things of that nature.

204
00:10:19,480 --> 00:10:20,630
So, there is a window.

205
00:10:20,630 --> 00:10:24,050
It's not an immediate requirement,
but it is one you wanna be aware of.

206
00:10:24,050 --> 00:10:28,630
And you do have the ability,
try get somebody in your business, or

207
00:10:28,630 --> 00:10:31,560
a peer, or colleague that you know,
to do an endorsement for you.

208
00:10:31,560 --> 00:10:35,190
If they can speak to your experience,
or if there's a sitting SSCP in good

209
00:10:35,190 --> 00:10:38,690
standing, meaning somebody who's already
certified, they can vouch for you,

210
00:10:38,690 --> 00:10:39,530
on your application.

211
00:10:39,530 --> 00:10:42,509
In effect, they do what's called an
endorsement, and they can simply sign off

212
00:10:42,509 --> 00:10:45,543
on the application saying they've known
you, they know the kind of work you do.

213
00:10:45,543 --> 00:10:48,665
And they are familiar with you,
and are willing to stand up for

214
00:10:48,665 --> 00:10:52,100
you if asked, to validate that you
should be able to become an SSCP.

215
00:10:52,100 --> 00:10:56,439
And by doing that, you then are able to
validate the requirements we have listed

216
00:10:56,439 --> 00:11:01,100
for you rather, in terms of making sure
that you can validate your experience.

217
00:11:01,100 --> 00:11:04,510
You also will be required to subscribe

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don examine the various access controls that can be implemented by security professionals to increase confidentiality in a modern network.
episodes.title: Access Controls

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don take a look at the bureaucratic side of IT security. They discuss the differences policies, procedures, guidelines and baselines as well as recommend several third parties vendors that provide templates.
episodes.title: Security Ops and Administration

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don examine project management techniques that can be used to assist implementing security standards. They also take a look at the common criteria specification and some of the history behind modern security infrastructure.
episodes.title: Security Ops and Administration Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don describe the various components of a security audit and highlight the target areas that a security professional should focus on while monitoring for security.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Analysis

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike cover patch management, firewall generations. They also discuss goals of security testing as well as the five phases of penetration testing.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Analysis Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike discuss risk response and recovery. They define some of the basic concepts involved in risk management as well as cover controls, countermeasures and the basic risk management process.
episodes.title: Risk Response and Recovery

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike continue risk management by covering policies, incident handling, forensic and recovery alternatives. They conclude with a rundown of disaster recovery planning.
episodes.title: Risk Response and Recovery Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike cover the basics of cryptography. They define some of the terminology necessary to understand cryptography.
episodes.title: Cryptography

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don explain the difference between symmetric, asymmetric and hybrid encryption systems. They also describe and demonstrate the function of hashing algorithms.
episodes.title: Cryptography Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike cover the various components of a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI). They discuss several types of attacks against cryptography such as brute force attacks and attacks against symmetric block ciphers.
episodes.title: Cryptography Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike take a look at basic network components. They discuss different network topologies such as LAN and WAN topologies. They discuss how we can implement these components and topologies in a secure fashion.
episodes.title: Networking

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don examine wide area network technologies. They break down the most common technologies most commonly seen in the field and examine the differences between them. They wrap up the episode discussing security appliances like firewalls and NAC.
episodes.title: Networking Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike discuss several protocols and port numbers. They break down several network protocols, routing protocols and security protocols. They also cover wireless standards and wireless best practices.
episodes.title: Networking Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don list and describe the many categories of malicious software. They also take a look at social engineering and wrap up the episode discussing the five steps in the hacking process.
episodes.title: Malicious Code
